text: [Music] hey this is Mel strong and welcome to my lecture on humidity part 2 if you haven't watched part 1 I suggest you go and do that first then this one will probably make a lot more sense so to recap from last time we talked about two methods that we use to describe humidity one was mixing ratio and the other was dewpoint now mixing ratio is probably the one that's the

easiest to visualize and it's describing how many grams of water vapor are in each kilogram of air so it has units of grams per kilogram dew point it's a little more abstract but it describes at what temperature the air would become saturated so if I say the dew point is 40 degrees one of the things that that tells you is that if I cool it down the four degrees tonight I will get condensation or do so both of these are used to describe humidity and

what we're going to do is we're going to talk a little bit about how we might be able to change those two variables so let's imagine I add water to the air somehow so you can imagine maybe I'm boiling a pot of water and water is evaporating out of my pot going into the air then how is that affecting the dew point in the mixing ratio of the air so if I can add water to the air any by any means both the mixing ratio and the dew point will increase now the converse is

also true if I remove water from the air both mixing ratio and dew point will both decrease now key idea here you cannot change one without changing the other so think about mixing ratio if I add water to the atmosphere I can think of it like I'm adding grams of water to the atmosphere mixing ratio must go up but if I add more water to the atmosphere that means I don't have to cool it as much before it becomes saturated so the

dew point also goes up so if one goes up the other must go up if one goes down the other must go down it's impossible to change dewpoint or mixing ratio eat either way up or down without changing the other one in the same way so keep that in mind now we also talked a little bit about how you might change dew point last time and same goes for mixing ratio which is often the a change in wind direction will result in a change in dew

point or mixing ratio so for New Mexico where we live if we get a twin coming say from the north or the Northwest that wind has come from somewhere cold and cold air is always dry air so generally that equates to low dew points low mixing ratios if we get wind coming from the south east that usually comes from a location that's pretty warm and has pretty high dew points and high mixing ratios so those values will go up now

this is also true pretty much no matter where you live in the United States if you're getting a north wind that wind probably came from somewhere up in Canada where it was cold and dry if you hear the wind coming from the south it probably came from somewhere more humid in your mixing ratios and dew points will increase as a result so what what I'm going to do is show some practice problems here and these are all problems that are kind of revolved around this concept so we'll go through the questions and we'll go over the answers

here so here's the first one says the mixing ratio in this room today is 3 grams per kilogram okay the temperature in here is 70 degrees Fahrenheit so I go and I just turn up the thermostat in a room and then warm up the room to 80 how has the mixing ratio changed so here's a choices mixing ratio increased decreased didn't change or not enough information to answer okay so so all we've done is we've warmed up the room okay so when you have a question like

this you ask yourself okay did I add water to the air or did I subtract water from the air now all I've done is raise the temperature so I did not add any water to the air I did not subtract any water from the air so the mixing ratio is still three grams per kilogram now the reason I'm giving you this question is because in the past some students get confused once we learned how temperature changes maximum mixing ratio they tend to one that try to change the mixing

ratio itself with temperature so in other words a lot of people on this question would say oh it's warmer it's a warmer temperature therefore the mixing ratio went up no not unless we added water okay so in this case the mixing ratio has not changed okay let's look at another one pot of water boiling on the kitchen stove the windows and doors are all closed so we are air in our house is sealed how is the dewpoint inside the kitchen changing increasing

decreasing not changing not enough information to answer okay so if I'm boiling water on the stove then clearly I am adding water molecules up into the air as the water is boiling or assuming the pot is open water molecules are coming out and going into the air in the kitchen so if we're adding water to the air in the kitchen that's going to increase dewpoints and this one the dew point would be increasing so another

one tonight dew starts to form on the grass outside as it does so how is the dew point changing overnight increasing decreasing doesn't change not enough information okay so if do is forming that means we are we have condensation if we have condensation that means that we're taking water molecules and we're bringing them down and we're putting them onto the grass onto the ground somewhere and that is removing water from the air we have to remove water

from the air to make do okay so if we're making do we're removing water from the air and that is decreasing the dew point okay so we're going to decrease the dew point as we remove water from the air to make the dew which of the following locations most likely has the highest annual average dew point and so if you're unfamiliar with these places you can kind of look

at them on a map but we're last time if you remember we looked on the internet at Earth Knoll Schoolnet and we looked at where most of the water vapor in the world is and it's along a band kind of near the equator so if you live somewhere we're surrounded by warm ocean and you have warm temperatures you're gonna have pretty high dew points so of these choices Miami is probably your best bet for having highest average dew point okay dew point in this room was 50

for temperature is 75 I turned the thermostat up so the room warms to 80 how has a dew point changed okay so once again you ask yourself did I add water to the air J subtract water from the air or did I not add or subtract any water from the air so all I did here is so we know the dew points 54 temperatures 75 so if I increase the temperature have I

added water to the air no if I subtracted water from the air no dew point still 54 okay so dew point has not changed okay similar to one that always seemed just a minute ago a pot of what a water is boiling on the kitchen stove windows and doors are all closed how is the mixing ratio inside the kitchen changing so again if you're boiling water on the stove that water is coming out of the pot going into the air we're literally

adding grams of water to the air so that mixing ratio is increasing wind has been blowing from the west for several days suddenly shifts directions and starts blowing from the east how's the dew point likely change so we just kind of talked about this so if it's coming from the West it's coming from off the Pacific Ocean the Pacific Ocean is very cold and the dew points are usually going to be very low over here coming from the east if we trace that ear back somewhere it

probably came over maybe the Atlantic or maybe the Gulf of Mexico and the dew points were pretty high so most likely the dew point has increased ok dew point in this room is fifty four temperature is 75 I turned the thermostat down so the room cools to 40 does the air become saturated in other words another way of asking this is do we make do in our room

so in order to answer that I need to know the dew point 54 okay then I need to know are we cooling it down to or below the dew point yes we're cooling it down to 40 that's below 54 so we are going to make do we are going to saturate the air so yes same question except I added one more sentence does the dew point change okay

so to illustrate what happens here let's consider I got two thermometers one measures temperature one measures dewpoint let's say okay so right now the temperature is above dew point and let's say I cool down the room all right or maybe this is happening outside doesn't matter so I cool it down 10 degrees temperatures drop 10 degrees dew point

has not changed why is dew point not changed we haven't taken any water or added any water from the atmosphere cool it down further now it's 60 dew point still hasn't changed same amount of water in the air now we drop it down to 50 and at 50 degrees air is saturated okay so from this point forward we're gonna start making do so right at 50 where the temperature equals the dew point right at this point right here both of those values are the same

the air is saturated and what we would get at this instant in time would be like microscopic do tiny tiny little particles you could hardly see but as a COO it further below 50 those little Dew droplets we're gonna start to grow larger and larger now as I start to grow do larger and larger I have to take water molecules out of the air and put them down onto the ground like the grass or if this is happening inside to beyond

the walls so here we are 50 I'm going to cool it further down to 40 and notice what happens dew point has to change with temperature so if the temperature drops to 40 the dew point also has to drop to 40 and if I drop it further to 30 the dew point still has to follow the temperature and also go down to 30 one of the laws to keep in mind in your head dew point can never be higher in

temperature ok dew point can never be higher than temperature so here they're the same you can have temperature higher than dew point but you can't have dew point higher than temperature ok ok monsoon season in New Mexico and we notice that over several days the dew point is decreasing right so let's imagine worth it's in August and we

notice that the dew point has been decreasing for several days how will this most likely affect our weather so if dew point goes down that means there was less water molecules in the air if there's less water molecules in the air you're gonna have a harder time making precipitation right so if you want to make a cumulonimbus a thunderstorm you need to have water vapor available for that to happen so when dew point goes down the chance of precipitation goes down with it

usually so most likely we would have a lower chance of precipitation ok story problem dew point is 52 today does not change for the next 24 hours it's sunrise a temperature of 68 by noon the temperature is 85 by 4 the temperature is 94 when do we have the highest concentration of water molecules in the air is that sunrise is it at noon is it at 4:00 the amount of

water in the air doesn't change not enough information to determine so what do you think about that one so the key to this question is in the first sentence it says the dew point is 52 and does not change for the next 24 hours so the only way I can change dew point is to add water to the air or subtract water from the air the fact that the dew point is not changing it tells me does not change for 24 hours so the amount of

water in the air is not going to change for 24 hours so d the amount of water in the air does not change so you have to in your mind keep separate temperature from dew point temperature can effectuate up and down every day dew point often remains constant all day long for day after day after day sometimes so today we're introducing a third way to describe humidity which is relative humidity turns out relative

humidity is the most common way that humidity is described to the general public but it's also completely misunderstood by almost everybody we're going to talk about why it's so confusing in a minute but you've probably heard relative humidity before in a weather report they might say something like the relative humidity is 35% okay so before we explain what that means let's make a point to explain what it does not mean it does not mean that the air is 35% water vapor because in

the last lecture one of the things we talked about is that water vapor ranges somewhere between zero and almost 4% of the total of gases in the atmosphere so there's no way that it could be 35% of total gases so it does not mean that we can define relative humidity as this fraction where we're looking at the current mixing ratio that's on the top divided by the maximum possible mixing ratio at the current temperature

on the in the denominator now for this class generally speaking you're going to be given the the top you're going to be given what the current mixing ratio is and the bottom number we're going to have to look up from the table that we had last time so then we take that fraction and we multiply it by hundred to turn it into a percent so relative humidity is given as a percent between zero and 100 percent so what does this tell you well the percentage tells you

how close you are to saturation so 100% relative humidity means the air is saturated meaning it can't hold any more water vapor okay so we're gonna do a sample problem and here's an example of the type of problem that we would see so mixing ratio is 4 grams per kilogram the temperature is 80 degrees Fahrenheit what is the relative humidity so the first thing I do is I write out the

definition of relative humidity it's a current mixing ratio divided by the maximum possible possible mixing ratio at the current temperature times a hundred okay so what do we know so the current mixing ratio is given to us that's 4 grams per kilogram so put that in on the top now the maximum possible mixing ratio at the current temperature the temperature is 80 degrees I've got to go back to the graph that we used

last time here is 80 degrees the maximum possible mixing ratio 20 7.01 grams per kilogram so I'm going to put that in 20 7.01 Bram's per kilogram times 100 all right so I'm going to do that calculation 4/20 7.01 times 100 and I get 14.8% okay

so that's my relative humidity all right so now what I'm gonna do is I'm going to change the problem by just changing one little thing which is let's go back to the original problem and let's say that it's 80 degrees in the afternoon when all this happens and then the Sun Goes Down and becomes cooler and it cools off overnight and it cools down to 50 degrees and everything else stays the

same the mixing ratio is still the same so let's make a new calculation of relative humidity all right so back to this what do we know well we know that the top of the fraction is still the same but now the bottom of the fraction has a different number because we're at the different temperature so I go back to the table 50 degrees the maximum

possible mixing ratio is 9.2 4 grams per kilogram so I'm gonna put that in 9.2 4 grams per kilogram times 100 ok so now we will do that math so I've got 4/9 point 2 4 times 100 is forty three point three percent okay so here is the point

and this is a really important one where I'm gonna say this more than once the relative humidity was about 15 percent and then it jumps up to 43 so more than doubles right so if I went to the average person on the street and I told them that this morning or this afternoon the relative humidity was about 15 percent and then tonight it went up it more than doubled most people would

think that we must have more water in the air because relative humidity went up if the relative humidity doubled most people would think oh we must have double the amount of water in the air because that's what humanity describes except that's not what happened because the mixing ratio is the same for both of these the mixing ratio tells us how much water is in the air there's four grams for every box you know every one kilogram box of air so the relative

humidity went up not because there's more water in the air but just because it's a cold air temperature this is why relative humidity is so confusing to people the general public thinks that when relative humidity goes up the air got more humid there's more water in the air but in fact that's not what happened at all the amount of water in this case stayed exactly the same what happened was we went to a colder temperature and the colder temperature meant we were dividing by a smaller number which gave

us a bigger answer so what this really tells us is that initially we were pretty far from saturation about 15% we got closer to the saturation we're still a long ways away but that's all this really tells us is that the air became closer to saturation but the amount of water in this case stayed exactly the same in both instances and that is why relative humidity is so confusing so with relative humidity a lot of times

we're not so much interested in the actual numbers as much as we want to know if relative humidity is going to increase decrease or stay the same so if you've got one of those problems first thing to do is write out the definition of relative humidity which we said is the current mixing ratio divided by the maximum possible mixing ratio at the current temperature now these problems that we're going to see we're gonna we're trying to figure out how relative humidity is gonna change so we're going to change the temperature we're gonna change the mixing ratio so even though

keep in mind that even though I use the word current in here we're projecting into the future of some that's gonna happen so it won't be current so what you would do is with a given problem is write this out and think okay is that is the mixing ratio gonna increase decrease or stay the same and then is the maximum possible mixing ratio on the increase decrease or stay the same once you figure that out you

can figure out whether the overall answer the relative humidity itself is going to increase decrease or stay the same but you don't actually have to do any math you're just trying to reason out which way it's gonna go so I do a couple of examples here so the mixing ratio today stays constant throughout the day how does the relative humidity this afternoon compared to this morning so we're going on the assumption here that this afternoon is warmer than this morning normal day okay so then we write

out the definition of relative humidity and think about okay is the numerator gonna change is it denominator going to change so let's start with the top is the mixing ratio going to change here it says mixing ratio today stays constant so the top of this fraction is going to stay constant throughout the day because we're told that the bottom though maximum possible mixing ratio at the current temperature the temperature itself is going to change and so we from the chart we know that if we increase

the temperatures throughout the day the maximum possible mixing ratios are also going to increase so that tells us that the bottom of this fraction is going to increase as the day gets warmer so that means we're taking a number even though we don't know what the number is and we're dividing it by another number that's getting bigger if you divide by a bigger number you get a smaller answer so from this then we can predict that

the relative humidity is going to decrease as the day gets warmer we're dividing by a bigger and bigger number as the day goes on so do another one here you put a sealed box of air into the refrigerator as it cools how does the relative humidity change so by sealed box we can assume that there's no water that goes in or out of the box there's some amount of water vapor in the box we don't know how much so we don't know the current mixing ratio but the way the problem set up it's not going to change

well the bottom of this change yes we are assuming that we've got air that is probably room temperature we're putting it in the refrigerator it's going to start cooling and so again from the table as we cool down the temperatures we're going to have smaller and smaller maximum possible mixing ratios so in this case the bottom part of this fraction is becoming smaller so now you're taking a number you don't know the number but whatever it is you're

dividing it by a smaller and smaller number as it gets colder and colder so what happens to the answer it gets bigger if you divide by a smaller number you get a bigger answer so the relative humidity increases as this box gets colder let's do another example so sprinklers come on in our yard in they stay on for 30 minutes and says during this time the temperature outside does not change how does the relative humidity change so could we change the

top part of this fraction well for sending streams of water through the air and tiny droplets there's a very good chance that a lot of that water at least a portion of it is going to evaporate and we're going to add water molecules to the atmosphere right that's not what a sprinkler is trying to do sprinklers trying to sprinkle the grass but it goes through the air and you're guaranteed to have some evaporation so if we have evaporation we're going to increase think of it as increasing the grams of water in the air we're increasing the

top part of this fraction what about the bottom well the bottom depends on the temperature but the temperature says is not changing right so the bottom part of this fraction stays the same so the top part gets larger the bottom part stays the same so overall my answer is going to increase so relative humidity increases as we water to the hair okay here's another example it's a little different so on

Monday the relative humidity is 25% on Tuesday the relative humidity is 45% on which day was there more water vapor in the air okay so what's clear from this question is that the relative humidity increases right so let's think about why that might have happened could we increase the relative humidity by increasing the numerator of this fraction so yes if we increase the mixing ratio then that

would make the relative humidity go up so that could be a possibility but we could also make that number bigger if we're dividing by a smaller number so if I decrease this number and how would I decrease this number I could decrease this number if I made it colder so one possibility is I could have made the top number larger another possibility is I could make the bottom number smaller either way could have get could get me

from 25% to 45% the problem is without enough information I actually don't know which of those two things happen or maybe it's a little bit of both so this is the problem with relative humidity if I told you the dew point increases you know the amount of water in the atmosphere had to increase have I tell you the mixing ratio increases you know the amount of water and the atmosphere had to increase if I tell you the

relative humidity increases without more information you don't know if I added more water to the air or if I just made it colder or a little bit of both so relative humidity is ambiguous and a lot of times when we're dealing with relative humidity we just don't have enough information to answer questions like this so few more facts about relative humidity a few things to keep in mind when temperature equals dew

point your air is saturated and your relative humidity is a hundred percent okay so remember that one inside a cloud relative humidity always a hundred percent or fog fog is a cloud on the ground you can't have relative humidity over a hundred percent okay at least not in this class so if you're doing the math and you come up with a number over a hundred he did something wrong all right the relative humidity usually cycles over 24

hours whereas dewpoint mixing ratio usually do not okay so let me explain that one a little bit more so if we measure temperature every hour throughout a 24 hour cycle day after day we would notice that the temperature is cycle right it gets warms up during the day the hottest time is usually late afternoon then it cools down and then the coldest

time in the 24 hour period is usually right before the Sun rises and then the cycle continues again right we have this call sign wave curve of temperature well what we said now several times is that relative humidity depends on the temperature that's on the bottom of that fraction that we keep talking about so what that means is where the temperature is the warmest we would expect the relative humidity to be the lowest and

where the temperature is the lowest we would expect relative humidity to be the highest so this is the kind of graph that you expect to see with relative humidity in a normal 24 hour day the dew point in the mixing ratio don't change very much in fact usually especially here in New Mexico day after day after day you typically have a pretty constant dew point usually okay but the relative humidity is always in a 24-hour cycle

because the temperature is in a 24-hour cycle so we typically see the lowest relative humidities the hottest part of the day then they rise at night so we see the highest relative humidities at night and then the cycle repeats again so again I keep repeating myself but it's really important to emphasize a lot of people are super confused about relative humidity if they have a little weather station they look at it and it's night and they see the relative humidity go up they think oh there's there's more

humid there's more water in the air but no that's not what's happening the only thing that's happening is a temperature as increase temperature has decreased in the night time which makes the relative humidity increase so with all this confusion then good question would be why in the world that were using relative humidity at all in fact when I started this I said that we use relative humidity more than the other two variables so one of the reasons is that

it's related to human comfort or discomfort so you've probably experienced these at some point if you have a hot day with high relative humidity you feel miserable and we'll talk more about this in the next lecture but a lot of it has to do with the evaporation or the lack thereof of your sweat in fact there are something called the heat index sometimes referred to as a misery index and on the y-axis here we

have relative humidity so there are 0% to a hundred percent this is the temperature from 70 to 110 and these boxes are what it feels like to you that's the heat index so you'll notice that for example if you have low relative humidity it actually will feel cooler than it really is right so if it's a hundred degrees outside but the relative you made it is 0% then it feels like it's about 91 okay

so that's nice but of course what's not nice is when you get too high relative humidity right so if you have a 100 degree day and 80 percent relative humidity you end up with a heat index of 157 meaning it feels like it's a hundred fifty seven outside so in New Mexico we don't really talk about this too much we don't have much of a heat index here because a relative humidities are usually kind of especially in the summer they're kind of in this range up in here

so we really don't have to worry about this too much if you live in the southeast for example they deal with this a lot now what we do get in New Mexico a lot is the second one here hot date and low relative humidity that produces desiccation meaning that your skin dries out right so you know when we have these days especially in New Mexico they occur usually in June is is the time where we have the hottest temperatures and the lowest relative humidity in your lips are dry and your

skin is dry and your itchy all that stuff right so that's because a little relative humidity and then it also affects the way you feel cold temperatures as well so when it's cold and the relatively relative humidity is high it does feel colder to you another reason that we use relative humidity is for fire danger so when you have low relative humidity that means it's much easier to start a fire and then once the

fire starts it's much easier for that fire to keep burning and then finally it's related to evaporation rate and we're going to talk about this in the next lecture but when you have low relative humidity you have very rapid evaporation so let's go back this is a question that they had the beginning of this lecture temperature in this classroom of 75 the dew point is 54 I changed the thermostat and the temperature rises to 85 degrees as the

room warms up what happens dew point increases dew point decreases dew point doesn't change not enough information well in this case if I just increase the temperature I'm not increasing the amount of water in the air I'm not decreasing the amount of water in the air dew point does not change okay so this is what we're saying in the beginning of this lecture that when we increase temperature and we decrease temperature if we're not adding or subtracting water

dew points and mixing ratios don't change I take this exact same problem and they just change one thing instead of dew points I change it to relative humidity now as I warm the room up the bottom of the fraction of relative humidity changes right so this is a typical problem that you might face so as I warm the room up I'm dividing by a number that's getting

bigger so my overall answer is getting smaller so in this case the relative humidity decreases so this is what you got to keep track of you got to keep track of dew point mixing ratio and relative humidity if you add water to the air what will do each of those do if you subtract water from the air what do each of those do if you increase the temperature what to each of those do when you lower the temperature what do each of those do okay so again if you're one of my students on
